journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part A: Journal of Power and Energy

title-group.article-title: Effect of tip clearance on impeller discharge flow and vaneless diffuser performance of a centrifugal compressor

article-meta.aff: 1Turbopump Department, Korea Aerospace Research Institute, Korea
2Laboratory for Energy Conversion, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, Switzerland

author-notes.corresp: Soon-Sam Hong, Turbopump Department, Korea Aerospace Research Institute, Daejeon 305-333, Korea. Email: sshong@kari.re.kr

abstract.p: To see the tip clearance effect on a centrifugal compressor, time-resolved flow measurements are carried out at the discharge of a centrifugal compressor impeller with a diameter of 280 mm. The impeller is 30° back swept and is operated at a blade tip speed of 260 m/s, which is a rather high speed for measuring time-resolved flow. Six levels of tip clearance ratio ranging from 0.06 to 0.21 were tested. A fast response aerodynamic probe equipped with a single pressure sensor is used for the flow measurements. The correlation between the impeller efficiency and the tip clearance is presented. The mean flow variation from hub to shroud is obtained and its dependence on the tip clearance is discussed. The measured time-resolved flow at impeller exit differs from the classical jet-wake flow model. Four kinds of flow patterns (blade wake, jet, channel wake, and tip clearance flow) are observed at the impeller discharge plane. By increasing the tip clearance, the total pressure loss in the vaneless diffuser decreases, while the impeller loss increases. One-dimensional flow calculations of the vaneless diffuser show that the matching constant of a skin friction coefficient is decreased by increasing the tip clearance.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In many turbomachines impellers are not shrouded. The performance of impellers is deteriorated by the pressure loss caused by the clearance between the shroud casing and the tips of the impeller blades. Therefore, it is important to estimate the effects of the tip clearance correctly for the design of turbomachines. The effect is conventionally expressed for impellers as a loss in efficiency. Pampreen1 used measurements over a range of clearances on six different compressors and found that the averaged decrement in efficiency was described by (1)Δη/η=-0.3CR where CR is the tip clearance ratio and is defined as the ratio of axial tip clearance to the blade width at the impeller exit, and η is the efficiency. Senoo and Ishida2 developed a simple model for the tip loss, using momentum normal to the blades and Bernoulli’s equation for the pressure difference. The decrement in efficiency was found to be almost proportional to the tip clearance ratio, if this ratio was less than 0.1. The trend seems to be (2)Δη/η=-0.25CR For example, there is a 1% loss in efficiency for every four percent of tip clearance ratio.

Chriss et al.3 and Harthaway and Wood4 emphasized the importance of throughflow wake, which is largely fed by the tip clearance flow when the centrifugal impeller is throttled. Eisenlohr and Chladek5 described the possibilities for optimizing passive tip clearance control by design features and suggested that transient expansion processes must be considered when using a thermal tip clearance control.

Many models1,2,6,7 have been proposed for tip loss in the centrifugal compressor based on performance measurements and numerical calculation, but there is few detailed flow measurements. Goto8 measured the discharge flow from a mixed-flow pump impeller in five cases of tip clearance, and the flow fields were investigated by applying the incompressible version of a computational fluid dynamic code. Ishida et al.9 measured the discharge flow from low-speed centrifugal impellers with blade tip speeds of approximately 50 m/s and discussed the secondary flow due to the tip clearance. Schleer and Abhari10 measured the discharge flow from a centrifugal compressor impeller for two cases of tip clearance by using 3D laser Doppler anemometry, and their discussion focused on the flow field at part load condition. Schleer et al.11 measured time-resolved pressure along the shroud casing of the centrifugal impeller of Schleer and Abhari,10 and their discussion focused on the onset of instability.

The discharge flow from centrifugal compressor impellers is very complex, and it is conceptually divided into two regions. Typically the division is between jet which is an isentropic, core flow and the wake which is a non-isentropic region containing substantial losses. Jet-wake flow pattern, which was introduced by Dean and Senoo12 and called the classical jet-wake model, is shown in Figure 1. Relative velocity and radial velocity are higher in the jet region than those of the wake region, but tangential velocity is lower in the jet region as shown in Figure 1. Eckardt13 showed experimentally that the jet is found on the hub pressure side and the wake on the shroud suction side of the blade. Figure 1.
Jet-wake flow pattern.12

A vaneless diffuser, which is located downstream of a centrifugal impeller, is widely used in centrifugal compressors and pumps. The vaneless diffuser is a simple component of turbomachines, but its aerodynamic behavior is very complicated. Early efforts to predict the performance of the vaneless diffuser assume that the flow is one-dimensional.14–16 Total pressure losses are determined by the use of a wall friction coefficient which accounts for both the actual wall shear stress and the change of momentum flux. Johnston and Dean17 assume that the overall diffuser total pressure loss is the sum of the sudden expansion mixing loss at the diffuser inlet and the friction loss in the following diffuser region. Japikse18 recommended an empirical expression for the skin friction for use with one-dimensional analysis. Japikse19 discusses appropriate values of the skin friction coefficient for centrifugal compressor applications.

In the present study, time-resolved flow measurements are performed at the discharge of a centrifugal compressor impeller at a blade tip speed of 260 m/s, which is a relatively high speed for measuring time-resolved flow. In order to investigate the tip clearance effect, six levels of tip clearance are tested. The time-resolved flow field as well as the mean flow field is examined. The tip clearance effect of centrifugal compressors has been studied mostly in regard to the impeller performance or the overall stage performance, but there is little research about the performance of vaneless diffusers. In this article, the tip clearance effect on the vaneless diffuser as well as on the impeller is discussed.

sec.title: Test rig
sec.p: All the experiments are carried out in a research facility at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, Zurich (ETH, Zurich). The facility is a closed-loop test rig and air is used as a working fluid. The single-stage, industrial centrifugal compressor has an unshrouded impeller and is driven by a 440 kW DC motor coupled to a two-stage gear box. A flow straightener mounted in the suction pipe ensures axial flow at the stage inlet. The inlet condition is set to a pressure of 980 mbar and a temperature of 24 °C during the measurements.

The impeller has 22 blades, an inlet diameter of 175 mm, an outlet diameter of 280 mm, an exit blade width of 16.8 mm, and an exit blade angle of 60° from tangent (Figure 2 and Table 1). This is the baseline impeller used in Schleer et al.20 The measurements are made at 17,720 r/min, which is in the high subsonic regime and corresponds to an impeller tip Mach number of 0.75 (U2 = 260 m/s). A vaneless diffuser with parallel walls is used here. The diffuser is followed by a large toroidal collecting chamber providing circumferentially uniform pressure at the impeller outlet. Figure 2.
Tested centrifugal compressor impeller. Table 1.
Geometry and running condition of impeller.
Exit diameter 280 mm
Exit width 16.8 mm
Exit blade angle from tangent 60°
Blade number (full + splitter) 22 (11 + 11)
Rotational speed 17,720 r/min
Impeller tip Mach number 0.75

The overall stage performance of the compressor is measured by conventional wall pressure taps and temperature probes in the suction and outlet pipes. The mass flow rate, which is regulated by a throttle, is measured by a standard flow nozzle21 and is therefore estimated to be accurate within 1.0%.

The tip clearance is changed by shimming the shroud away from the impeller. The clearance is measured at the beginning with the minimum clearance, which is 1.0 mm, and then the thickness of the shim is added to the minimum clearance. Six values of clearance are tested as shown in Table 2. In the shroud region the flow might be influenced by the tip clearance, so more measurement points are set in place in the shroud region. As shown in Table 3, the flow measurements are carried out 7 mm downstream of the impeller exit, or r = 147 mm (r/r2 = 1.05), and at a vaneless diffuser region, or r = 171 mm (r/r2 = 1.22). Table 2.
Tested tip clearances.
t (mm) CR (= t/b2)
1.0 0.06
1.5 0.09
2.0 0.12
2.5 0.15
3.0 0.18
3.5 0.21
Table 3.
Flow measurement position.
Position r (mm) r/r2 Location Comments
2 140 1.00 Impeller exit –
3 147 1.05 Vaneless diffuser inlet Flow measurement
4 171 1.22 Vaneless diffuser region Flow measurement

sec.title: Instrumentation
sec.p:
Flow fields presented herein are measured with a single-sensor fast response aerodynamic probe, which is shown in Figure 3. A miniature pressure sensor chip of piezoresistive type is mounted in the probe. This probe has a tip diameter of 1.8 mm and is described in detail in Kupferschmied et al.,22 Roduner et al.,23 and Koeppel et al.24 In terms of the systematic fluctuations, this probe provides two-dimensional velocity and total and static pressure in steady and periodically unsteady flows. Figure 3.
Tip of flow measuring probe.

The probe is used at every traverse position in a pseudo-three-sensor mode. The fluctuating flow is measured in a time-resolved manner at three angular positions of the probe shaft. The center angle position is set to the time-averaged flow direction, which is known from earlier traverses. For the other two angle positions the probe is rotated in yaw by 43° clockwise and counterclockwise, respectively. In each yaw position the sensor signal is measured and stored. The circumferential position of the impeller blade is determined from a trigger on the impeller shaft that provides a once per revolution trigger signal. The trigger signal is stored together with the probe signals.

The mean value of the signal represents the overall pressure level and provides information on the flow direction. Signal fluctuations (AC part) are composed of deterministic (rotor position determined) and stochastic (e.g. turbulence induced) ones. By employing the phase-locked sampling and ensemble averaging technique over the revolutions, all stochastic fluctuations are statistically eliminated and the deterministic fluctuations are obtained over one rotation of the impeller.

In order to achieve a statistically significant number of events, the sampling rate of the data acquisition system is set to 200 kHz. With a rotational speed of 17,720 r/min (295 Hz) and a data collection time of 1.0 s at each yaw position, 295 revolutions, which are considered to be statistically sufficient, are measured and averaged. With a sampling rate of 200 kHz at a rotational frequency of 295 Hz, a resolution of 678 data points per revolution is achieved. This results in an angular resolution of about 0.5°.

The accuracy of the probe measurements is checked by mass balance. Mass flow calculated from the probe traverse is compared to the standard orifice measurements. The difference of the two mass flows at the vaneless diffuser inlet is less than 3%.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
The overall stage performance is measured for the six levels of tip clearance. The performance maps are shown in Figure 4, which plots the stage total pressure ratio versus corrected mass flow. The total pressure ratio is gradually decreased with an increase in the clearance. The right end of the performance curve is the intersection between the performance curve and the system resistance curve of the test rig, not the choke limit. Data which are measured at the medium mass flow (= 1.76 kg/s) are discussed in this article. Figure 4.
Stage total pressure ratio vs mass flow for all tip clearances investigated.

sec.title: Mean flow
sec.p:
The time-resolved flow parameters measured at a mass flow of 1.76 kg/s are mass-averaged over the circumferential and axial directions, and plotted against tip clearances in Figure 5. Velocity components normalized by the blade tip speed are shown in Figure 5(a). The relative velocity is composed of a radial velocity and a relative tangential velocity rΩ – Ct. The tip clearance has little influence on the absolute velocity and tangential velocity. The radial velocity decreases with an increase in the tip clearance, because the flow passage at the measured plane is increased by increasing the tip clearance and the density variation is small. Due to the radial velocity, the absolute and relative flow angles decrease with an increase in the tip clearance as shown in Figure 5(b). The tip clearance has little effect on the static and total temperature as shown in Figure 5(c). The total pressure decreases with an increase in the tip clearance, which could be expected from the stage performance curve shown in Figure 4. The static pressure curve is parallel to the total pressure curve because the absolute velocity is nearly constant with the changes in the tip clearance. The isentropic efficiency of the impeller is shown in Figure 5(e), where the efficiency is 0.945 at CR = 0.06. The total-to-total efficiency, which is defined as equation (3), is obtained from the total pressure and the total temperature measured at the inlet and the outlet of the impeller (3)η=((Pt/Pt0)(γ-1)/γ-1)/(Tt/Tt0-1) Using the data from Pampreen,1 Musgrave7 made the following linear correlation for the change in efficiency due to clearance (4a)Δη=-0.35CR+0.01 CR>0.03 (4b)Δη=0 CR≤0.03 The linear correlation obtained from the results in Figure 5(e) is as follows: Δη=-0.37CR+0.02. It is similar to equation (4a). Figure 5.
Mass averaged flow parameters vs tip clearance ratio at r/r2 = 1.05: (a) velocity component, (b) flow angle, (c) temperature ratio, (d) pressure ratio, (e) impeller efficiency.

The time-resolved flow parameters measured at m = 1.76 kg/s are mass-averaged over the circumferential direction, and plotted against the relative axial distance z/b2 in Figure 6, where the three levels of clearance (CR = 0.06, 0.12, and 0.18) are shown. As shown in Figure 6(a), the tip clearance has no effect on the absolute velocity up to z/b2 = 0.5, but has a small effect on the velocity near the shroud. With an increase in the tip clearance, the absolute velocity increases at z/b2 = 0.97, but decreases at the closest position to the shroud wall. For reference, the measurement positions closest to the shroud side diffuser wall are located 0.5 mm away from the wall. The static pressure distribution is flat across the width as shown in Figure 6(b). Total pressure and static pressure decrease with an increase in the tip clearance. The absolute flow angle in Figure 6(c) decreases from the hub to the shroud, and measures about 0° near the shroud for CR = 0.12 and 0.18. The radial velocity distribution is similar to that of the absolute flow angle. The static temperature linearly increases from the hub to the shroud and the total temperature is high in the mid passage. Both the static and total temperatures decrease by a small amount with an increase in the tip clearance. The isentropic efficiency of the impeller declines from hub to shroud and it decreases with an increase in the tip clearance as shown in Figure 6(f). The efficiency is higher than 1.0 locally at the hub region, but this kind of local high efficiency was also observed in Eckardt,13,25 Johnson and Moore,26 and Murakami et al.27 It may not be reasonable to plot the impeller efficiency from hub to shroud because the impeller efficiency is an overall parameter. However, the efficiency plot from hub to shroud is useful because it gives information about the loss. As we will see in the time-resolved flow, there is a low-loss flow in the hub region. Therefore the impeller efficiency on the hub is high as shown in Figure 6(f). Figure 6.
Mean flow parameters vs axial distance for three tip clearances ratio at r/r2 = 1.05: (a) absolute velocity, (b) pressure ratio, (c) absolute flow angle, (d) radial and tangential velocity, (e) temperature ratio, (f) impeller efficiency.

sec.title: Time-resolved flow
sec.p:
The time-resolved tangential and radial velocity components measured at m = 1.76 kg/s are shown in Figures 7 and 8 for three levels of tip clearance (CR = 0.06, 0.12, and 0.18). Contour plots of the velocity are presented in the figures, where the impeller blade tips projected on the radial direction are indicated by broken lines. F and S stand for the full blade and splitter blade, and PS and SS for the pressure side and suction side, respectively. The conceptual jet-wake flow pattern shown in Figure 1 has a one-dimensional shape, so there is no flow variation in the axial direction. But in the measured flow shown in Figure 7, there is a large variation of flow in the axial direction. Four kinds of flow pattern (blade wake, jet, channel wake, and tip clearance flow) are marked at CR = 0.06 in Figure 7. The blade wake, which has a high tangential velocity and is aligned with the blades, is observed near the surface of the blades. The radial velocity is low in the blade wake (in Figure 8). The jet, which has a low tangential velocity, is observed in the hub-pressure side corner of the full blade. The radial velocity is high in the jet (in Figure 8). The channel wake, which has a high tangential velocity, is observed in the shroud-suction side corner of the splitter blade. The radial velocity is low in the channel wake (in Figure 8). The tip clearance flow, which has a very low tangential velocity, is seen near the shroud. The radial velocity is very low in the tip clearance flow (in Figure 8). The lowest tangential velocity, the lowest radial velocity, and a very large slip velocity are found in the tip clearance flow. The velocity triangles at CR = 0.06 of Figures 7 and 8 are shown in Figure 9. There is no flow slip in both jet and wake in Figure 1, but there is a flow slip in four kinds of flow pattern. Especially there is a significant flow slip in tip clearance flow. The relative flow angle is almost the same at the jet and the channel wake. Figure 7.
Time-resolved tangential velocity (Ct/U2) for three clearances at r/r2 = 1.05. Figure 8.
Time-resolved radial velocity (Cr/U2) for three clearances at r/r2 = 1.05. Figure 9.
Velocity triangles at r/r2 = 1.05 at CR = 0.06.

To note, the jet-wake structure downstream of the splitter blade (right half of the plot) is different from that downstream of the full blade (left half of the plot) in Figure 7. The channel wake core downstream of the splitter blade is located in the shroud-suction side corner and the jet and wake are divided diagonally from the hub-suction side corner to the shroud-pressure side corner. On the other hand, downstream of the full blade the wake core is located in the mid-shroud and the jet and wake are divided parallel to the shroud. The wake develops from the blade’s leading edge, but the leading edge positions of the full blade and the splitter blade are different, which implies that the jet-wake structures might be different each other.

The area of the tip clearance flow is enlarged by increasing the tip clearance. Local flow reversal is found near the shroud at CR = 0.18 in Figure 8. The channel wake region is large in the large tip clearance case. In Figure 8, the contour line shape is diagonal in the small tip clearance case, but it becomes more parallel to the shroud in the large tip clearance case.

The contour plot of the absolute total pressure is presented in Figure 10. The total pressure is higher at the channel wake and the blade wake than that of the jet region in the figure. It is known that the jet is an isentropic flow with no loss and that the wake is a non-isentropic flow with substantial losses. However, the concept is based on the relative frame of reference. The low momentum wake flow, as described with respect to the relative frame, can actually have a higher energy or momentum level in the absolute frame. Figure 10.
Time-resolved total pressure (Pt/Pt0) for three clearances at r/r2 = 1.05.

sec.title: Losses in a vaneless diffuser
sec.p:
Flow measurements are also performed in the region of the vaneless diffuser in order to calculate the pressure loss in the vaneless diffuser, or the difference of total pressure between the vaneless diffuser inlet (Position 3, or r/r2 = 1.05) and the location of the vaneless diffuser (Position 4, or r/r2 = 1.22). The time-resolved flow parameters measured at the vaneless diffuser are mass-averaged over the circumferential and axial directions. The averaged total pressure and static pressure are plotted against tip clearance in Figure 11, where the total pressure and static pressure are decreased by increasing the tip clearance. The total pressure and static pressure at impeller exit are also decreased by increasing the tip clearance as shown in Figure 5(d). The total pressure loss coefficient, which is defined in equation (5), is shown in Figure 12. (5)K=Pt3-Pt4Pt3-P3 Total pressure loss in the vaneless diffuser is decreased by increasing the tip clearance in Figure 12. On the other hand, the impeller loss increases by increasing the tip clearance, or the impeller efficiency decreases, as shown in Figure 5(e). Figure 11.
Pressure ratio at r/r2 = 1.22. Figure 12.
Total pressure loss coefficient of vaneless diffuser.

One-dimensional flow calculations in the vaneless diffuser are performed in order to compare the measured data with the calculations. The equations of Stanitz16 (Appendix 2) are solved directly by a numerical integration technique between the vaneless diffuser inlet and the outer radius of the vaneless space. But, it is important to specify an appropriate friction coefficient in order to get reasonable predictions. Japikse18 recommended the following form of skin friction coefficient (6)Cf=k(1.8×105Re) where k is constant and Re is the Reynolds number defined as Re=2Cb/ν. Japikse19 tabulated the values of k deduced from tests at different flow rates on a turbocharger and a large compressor. The value of k ranged from 0.0056 to 0.025; a suggested working value was around 0.01. The constant k is calculated for the present test.

The calculations start from the diffuser inlet (r/r2 = 1.05), where the initial conditions are given, and proceed through the vaneless diffuser. The value of k to match the measured total pressure at r/r2 = 1.22 is obtained at each tip clearance case. The variation of k with the tip clearance is shown in Figure 13. The value of k for the present test ranges from 0.011 to 0.028, which is higher than the suggested working value of 0.01.19 The higher value of k is obtained for the present test probably because the present measurement is conducted near the inlet region of the vaneless diffuser. The constant k is obtained by using the data measured at r/r2 = 2.52 in Japikse,18 while the data at r/r2 = 1.22 is used at present case. The skin friction will be higher in the inlet where the flow is being established, as it is at the entry to a pipe. In addition, the non-uniform impeller flow is mixed out in the inlet region and the mixing loss is incorrectly attributed to skin friction. Figure 13.
Value of k in equation (6).

The distribution of the matching constant k in Figure 13 is very similar to the total pressure loss coefficient K in Figure 12. In the vaneless diffuser analysis of Stanitz,16 only the friction loss is considered but the other losses like the mixing loss are ignored. Therefore the friction loss forms the total loss in Stanitz.16 That is why the constant k and the coefficient K have the similar distribution to each other. The value of k is decreased with increasing the tip clearance as shown in Figure 13. The lower value of k at the large tip clearance is obtained probably because the jet-wake mixing loss decreases with increased tip clearance. Most of the mixing loss arises from the mixing of the radial velocity rather than the tangential velocity.28 By increasing the tip clearance, the level of the radial velocity at the impeller exit decreases because of the mass conservation as shown in Figure 5(a); therefore, the mixing loss decreases. In addition, Johnston and Dean17 showed that the mixing loss decreases by increasing the swirl parameter at the impeller exit. The swirl parameter is the ratio of the tangential velocity to the radial velocity. The variation of the swirl parameter at r/r2 = 1.05 with the tip clearance for the present case is shown in Figure 14. By increasing the tip clearance, the swirl parameter increases; therefore, the mixing loss decreases according to Johnston and Dean.17 Figure 14.
Swirl parameter at r/r2 = 1.05.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Detailed discharge flow measurements are carried out to investigate the effect of tip clearance on the flow and performance of a back swept centrifugal compressor impeller with a tip speed of 260 m/s. Six levels of tip clearance ratio ranging from 0.06 to 0.21 are tested and the results are summarized as follows:

An analysis is conducted for flow parameters measured at medium mass flow and r/r2 = 1.05. From the averaged flow parameters, which are mass averaged at the measured plane, total pressure, static pressure, radial velocity, and impeller efficiency decrease with an increase in the tip clearance. The slope of the linear correlation between the impeller efficiency versus the tip clearance ratio is −0.37.

The flow parameters are mass averaged over the circumference to see the axial variation of the mean flow parameters from hub to shroud. The static pressure is uniform from the hub to the shroud and the level decreases with an increase in the tip clearance. The tip clearance has a little influence on the absolute velocity distribution in the shroud region: with an increase in the tip clearance the absolute velocity increases at the same distance from the hub, but it decreases at the same distance from the shroud. The static temperature linearly increases from the hub to the shroud. The impeller efficiency decreases linearly from the hub to the shroud and the level decreases with increasing the tip clearance.

The measured time-resolved flow at impeller exit shows that there is a large variation of flow in the axial direction as well, while the flow has only circumferential variation in the classical jet-wake model. Four kinds of flow pattern are observed: blade wake, jet, channel wake, and tip clearance flow. The contour plot of total pressure shows that the wake region has higher total pressure than the jet region.

By increasing the tip clearance, the total pressure loss in the vaneless diffuser is decreased, while the impeller loss is increased. One-dimensional flow calculations in the vaneless diffuser show that the matching constant of the skin friction coefficient is decreased by increasing the tip clearance. A lower value of the matching constant at low tip clearance is obtained probably because the jet-wake mixing loss decreases with increased tip clearance.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

def.p: vaneless diffuser matching constant for skin friction coefficient
total pressure loss coefficient at vaneless diffuser
axial distance from hub to shroud
flow measurement location in vaneless diffuser

sec.title: Appendix 2
sec.p: Stanitz16 developed an analysis method for one-dimensional, compressible flow with friction and area change in vaneless diffusers with arbitrary profiles in the axial-radial plane. A single parameter of skin friction coefficient (Cf) is applied to both the radial and tangential momentum equations. When the method is applied to present parallel-walled vaneless diffuser with a radial plane, the following equations are obtained (7)CrdCrdr-Ct2r+CfC2sinαb+1ρdPdr=0 (8)CrdCtdr+CrCtr+CfC2cosαb=0 (9)1ρdρdr+1CrdCrdr+1r=0 (10)ρ=PRT (11)Tt=T+C22Cp
Equations (7) to (11) represent the radial momentum, tangential momentum, conservation of mass, equation of state, and conservation of energy, respectively.
